item.title: UN study links Iran's protest hotspots to water crisis zones
item.description:
The anti-government protests convulsing Iran since late December are rooted not only in economic collapse and political repression but in a deeper, environmental catastrophe that has reached an inflection point. Dwindling water supplies, poisonous air, and crumbling infrastructure have compelled Iranians to take to the streets in the deadliest uprising the country has seen in decades.

A new analysis published this week by Nima Shokri of the United Nations University reveals a pattern: protests are more likely to erupt in areas suffering from groundwater depletion, land subsidence, and water rationing. Provinces such as Tehran, Khuzestan in the southwest, and Isfahan in central Iran, all regions with high levels of protest, are grappling with acute water shortages and disputes over access.

item.title: Asian stocks climb as investors look past Trump tariff threats
item.description:
Asian markets climbed on Tuesday as investors looked past President Donald Trump's warning of higher tariffs on South Korean goods, choosing instead to track Wall Street's gains and position for a pivotal week of tech earnings and the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

The Kospi index rebounded sharply, rising over 2% and reclaiming the 5,000 level after earlier losses sparked by Trump's tariff announcement. The benchmark index had dipped in early trading before sentiment improved following comments from South Korea's presidential office indicating it had not been notified of any tariff plans in advance.

item.title: New AI tool identifies genes across species without lab experiments
item.description:
Researchers at Germany's Forschungszentrum Jülich and Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf have unveiled Helixer, an artificial intelligence tool that can identify genes directly from raw DNA sequences without requiring laboratory experiments or prior knowledge about the organism being studied. The results, published in Nature Methods, mark a major step forward in addressing a long-standing bottleneck in genome research.

Gene annotation—the process of locating genes within long strings of DNA letters—has long been one of the most challenging aspects of genome analysis. While genome sequencing was automated more than two decades ago, the interpretation of that data has lagged far behind. Helixer changes this by using deep learning combined with a hidden Markov model to detect typical features of genes, including start and stop signals and structural elements such as exons and introns.

item.title: AI tools accelerate solid-state battery research in Asia
item.description:
Researchers across Asia are leveraging artificial intelligence to transform how solid-state batteries are developed, with two major advances announced this week that could speed the transition from conventional lithium-ion technology to safer, more energy-dense alternatives.

A review article published in the journal AI Agent by Tohoku University researchers outlines how AI agents are moving beyond isolated predictions to coordinate multi-step research strategies for discovering solid electrolytes, the materials that could replace flammable liquid electrolytes in next-generation batteries. Meanwhile, a team at Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) has developed an AI framework that predicts cathode particle sizes with 86.6% accuracy while also indicating the reliability of its predictions.

item.title: India and China cut power emissions together for first time since 1973
item.description:
Power sector emissions in China and India declined simultaneously in 2025 for the first time in over five decades, according to a new report from the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA), as record clean energy deployment in both nations offset a surge in coal use in the United States and helped keep global emissions largely flat.

The last time both countries registered a simultaneous drop in coal power output was 1973, during the global oil crisis.

item.title: India and EU finalize free trade deal after two decades of talks
item.description:
India and the European Union finalized a free trade agreement on Tuesday after nearly two decades of negotiations, creating a market of 2 billion people and representing approximately 25 percent of global economic output. The announcement came at the 16th India-EU Summit in New Delhi, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi met with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Antonio Costa.

"Yesterday a big agreement was signed between the European Union and India. People are calling this the mother of all deals," Modi said while inaugurating India Energy Week in Goa via video conferencing. The agreement covers about one-third of global trade and is expected to remove tariff and non-tariff barriers on more than 90 percent of goods traded between the two sides.

item.title: Chinese scientists claim stealth bomber tech up to 62% faster
item.description:
Chinese aerospace scientists have developed an active flutter suppression system that enables flying wing aircraft to operate 62.5 percent faster than previously possible while retaining their stealth characteristics, according to peer-reviewed research published in December and announced by Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics last month.

The breakthrough addresses a fundamental limitation that has constrained stealth bomber designs for decades: the trade-off between radar invisibility and speed. While flying wing aircraft like the U.S. B-2 Spirit excel at evading detection, their tailless design makes them vulnerable to dangerous vibrations at high speeds, forcing designers to limit them to subsonic flight.

item.title: Ocean salinity patterns can nearly double extreme El Niño risk, study finds
item.description: A subtle pattern of ocean saltiness in the western Pacific during boreal spring can nearly double the odds of an extreme El Niño event, according to new research published in Geophysical Research Letters. The study, authored by researchers from Duke University and NOAA, challenges the traditional understanding of how these climate phenomena develop.

item.title: Hungary, Slovakia to sue EU over Russian gas import ban
item.description:
Hungary and Slovakia will file lawsuits at the European Court of Justice to challenge the European Union's decision to ban Russian gas imports by 2027, marking a rare direct legal confrontation between member states and Brussels over energy policy.

The announcements came after EU ministers formally approved the ban on Monday, with 24 countries voting in favor and Hungary and Slovakia voting against. Bulgarian officials abstained.

item.title: UNSW engineers discover solar cells can self-repair at atomic level
item.description:
Engineers at UNSW Sydney have developed a method to watch solar cells heal themselves in real time, revealing for the first time that ultraviolet damage can be reversed at the atomic level when cells are exposed to ordinary sunlight.

The research, published in Energy & Environmental Science, introduces a non-destructive monitoring technique that could reshape how solar panels are tested, manufactured, and certified for long-term outdoor use.

item.title: World marks 80 years since Auschwitz liberation
item.description:
Candles flickered at dawn Tuesday at the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin as people across the globe paused to observe International Holocaust Remembrance Day, reflecting on Nazi Germany's murder of millions and its attempt to annihilate Jewish life in Europe.

The annual commemoration falls on January 27, the anniversary of the 1945 liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau by Soviet forces. This year marks the 81st anniversary of that liberation, with the United Nations theme "Holocaust Remembrance for Dignity and Human Rights" guiding observances worldwide.

item.title: Milano Cortina 2026 Olympics races to make snow as winters warm
item.description:
Snowmaking crews at the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics are racing against time to prepare competition surfaces as climate change continues to shrink the windows of freezing temperatures needed to produce artificial snow.

With the opening ceremony scheduled for February 6 in Milan and Cortina d'Ampezzo, organizers have relied heavily on snowmaking infrastructure to supplement increasingly unpredictable natural snowfall in Italy's Alpine venues. Recent snowfall over the past weekend has provided relief, but the long-term trend is clear: winters are warming, and the margin for error is narrowing.

item.title: NASA and GE Aerospace complete first hybrid electric jet engine test
item.description:
NASA and GE Aerospace have completed the first ground test of an integrated hybrid electric jet engine designed to power commercial airliners, marking a major step toward more fuel-efficient aviation.

The demonstration, conducted in December at GE Aerospace's Peebles Test Operation facility in Ohio, tested a modified Passport turbofan engine fitted with electric motor-generators capable of transferring, extracting, and injecting power during flight operations. The companies announced the successful milestone on January 26.

item.title: Hybrids overtake petrol as EU's top-selling powertrain for first time
item.description:
Europe's auto market crossed a historic threshold in 2025 as hybrid-electric vehicles became the most popular powertrain choice among car buyers, surpassing petrol for the first time, while fully electric vehicles also outsold petrol cars in December, according to data released by the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association (ACEA) on Tuesday.

Hybrid-electric vehicles captured 34.5% of the EU market in 2025, overtaking petrol cars at 26.6%, marking a fundamental shift in European consumer preferences. Battery-electric vehicles claimed an additional 17.4% market share, while plug-in hybrids added 9.4%—meaning electrified vehicles of all types collectively accounted for over 61% of new car sales in the bloc.

item.title: China opens world's largest compressed-air energy storage plant
item.description:
China has commenced operations on the world's largest compressed-air energy storage facility in Jiangsu province, marking a technical milestone in the nation's effort to stabilize its rapidly expanding renewable energy grid.

The Guoxin Suyan Huai'an Salt Cavern Compressed Air Energy Storage Demonstration Project consists of two 300-megawatt non-combustion units with a total storage capacity of 2,400 megawatt-hours, according to Harbin Electric Corporation, which announced the completion on January 27.

item.title: Doomsday Clock moves to 85 seconds before midnight
item.description:
The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists advanced the Doomsday Clock to 85 seconds before midnight on Tuesday, marking the closest the symbolic timepiece has ever been to catastrophe. The four-second move from 89 seconds, set in January 2025, reflects what scientists say are intensifying nuclear threats, accelerating climate change, and the growing risks posed by artificial intelligence.

"The Doomsday Clock's message cannot be clearer," Alexandra Bell, president and CEO of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, said at the announcement. "Catastrophic destruction, primarily due to nuclear risks and other global threats," is becoming increasingly probable, according to the organization.

item.title: Carney rejects US claim he walked back criticism of Trump trade policy
item.description:
Prime Minister Mark Carney told President Donald Trump that Canada stands by its trade diversification strategy and recent deal with China during a phone call Monday, pushing back against claims from the Trump administration that he had backed down from his earlier criticism of American trade policy.

"I meant what I said in Davos," Carney told reporters Tuesday before a cabinet meeting in Ottawa. "Canada was the first country to understand the change in U.S. trade policy that he had initiated, and we're responding to that."

The call comes amid escalating tensions between Washington and Ottawa as the two countries prepare for a formal review of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement later this year. Trump had threatened over the weekend to impose 100% tariffs on Canadian goods if Canada proceeds with a trade agreement with China, posting on Truth Social that Prime Minister Carney was "gravely mistaken" if he thought Canada could become a "Drop Off Port" for Chinese products.

item.title: Chinese firm unveils plan to send humanoid robot to space
item.description: A Chinese humanoid robot has been directly connected to a low-Earth orbit satellite for the first time in the world, while a separate initiative aims to send a humanoid into space as a robot astronaut—two advances that underscore China's accelerating push into the burgeoning field of embodied artificial intelligence.

item.title: OpenAI launches dedicated team to accelerate AI use in science
item.description:
OpenAI has unveiled a dedicated team to transform the use of artificial intelligence in scientific research, positioning its GPT-5 model as a collaborative partner for mathematicians and scientists while urging policymakers to expand support for AI-driven discovery.

The initiative, called OpenAI for Science, was first announced in October 2025 and is led by Kevin Weil, a company vice president with a background in particle physics who nearly completed a PhD at Stanford before entering the tech industry.

item.title: Lunai Bioworks launches AI tool to block chemical weapon design
item.description:
Lunai Bioworks on Tuesday announced the deployment of Sentinel, a transformer-based AI safeguard designed to prevent large language models and scientific AI systems from generating novel chemical agents. The Sacramento-based biotech company said the technology embeds directly within foundation models to screen molecular outputs in real time, functioning as what CEO David Weinstein described as "the immune system for scientific AI."

"As AI models become more powerful, safety has to move closer to the core," Weinstein said in a statement. "Sentinel operates inside AI systems—not outside them—stopping dangerous chemical designs before they are ever produced."

The launch comes amid mounting concern over the dual-use risks of advanced AI in chemistry and biology, with major AI companies including Anthropic and OpenAI warning that powerful models could assist bad actors in developing biological and chemical threats.
